content.description: First bolted route around the corner from the south side. Steep, 25 foot face route. Scramble up easy cracks, then move out left above the big roof and climb up slightly overhanging face above.
content.protection: 3 bolts, 2 bolt anchor
content.location: First route on the far left side of the Overlook North side.

content.description: Face climb on small pockets and edges. One of the harder ticks at the Overlook, IMO.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Just right of Just Say No to Jugs.

content.description: This is an excellent less traveled wide crack that offers some good basalt climbing in a slightly overhanging hands to wide hands crack in left facing open book. Tricky opening moves to sustained climbing above the crux with a good rest or two.
content.protection: Camalots: 1-#.75, 2-#2, 3-#3, and 2-#4, some draws with low profile biners(spirits, positrons, or equivalent) for the anchors(to fit through the chain links) if you go to the Overlichen anchors(to the left). The chains are short and on stud bolts with washers. The Chocholate Thunder anchors to the right have bolt hangers + biners to lower from.
content.location: This route is the obvious crack in between Overlichen and Chocolate Thunder.

content.description: The offwidth crack just left of Huecos Rancheros might interest people looking to climb wide cracks-- it's one of the few in White Rock that stays wide for a decent length.  Crux down low, wider up high.This is "10. Unknown" in Jemez Rock.
content.protection: Gear from 3-6", but you will also need some probably smaller gear to build an anchor at the top, or perhaps sling boulders.
content.location: Just left of Huecos Rancheros

content.description:
A broad crack, with a wide flared section about 25 feet up (no offwidthing required, though). 

  Listed as #6 in Beverly (2006:156). Wa3lt's annotated ?? shows this as a line to the right of "3".
content.protection: Single set of hand- to fist-sized cams. Anchor at top.
content.location: Immediately to the right of Overlard; you'll be using some of that route's face holds as you pass the low roof to the left.

content.description: A broad crack in the back of a dihedral. Not remarkable, but one of the easiest lines at the Overlook; a good beginner lead and would be a good one to set a toprope for beginners.   Listed as #3 in Beverly (2006:156).  Wa3lt's annotated ?? shows only the very top of this crack (straight up from "2").
content.protection: Single set of hand- to fist-sized cams.  No established anchor on top.
content.location: Near the far east end of the north side, between View with a Room and  Overlord.

content.description: Toprope the face just around the corner from the Overlook SE side. Pretty fun, but short.
content.protection: TR
content.location: Left of View with a Room

content.description: The crux is through the middle section of this otherwise nice handcrack in a deep dihedral. It is a little dirty and loose at the top. Continue to the Dangle Your Participle anchors. This is a good warm up if you brought the rack.
content.protection: #1 and #2 Link cams, a #1, #2, #3, And #4 Camalots. Take a shoulder runner for The #4 at the top to reduce rope drag. Then a 2 bolt chained anchor to the right.
content.location: The handcrack in between Vasoconstrictor and Dangle Your Participle.

content.description: This route stars up a moderate and featured ramp to the first clip, then desperately crank up painful crimps and shallow pockets up an overhanging wall past two more bolts. Continue to the exit mantle up onto the top shelf.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a 2 Bolt chained anchor.
content.location: This is the first bolted line to the right of Huecos Rancheros.

content.description: Clip the first bolt of Lubeme then trend right into a gully with a lot of thin face moves that are pretty continuous for the grade. This might be considered a sandbag by many, but it is still an OK route. The crux is getting into the gully and then the exit to the anchors.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the furthest bolted route to the right(west) end of the North Side of Overlook.

content.description:
Climb choss to a bouldery start on top of a chossy block tower, as for Overkill, then left after 2nd bolt.  Follow the overhanging prow with small pockets on the left and sidepulls right of the arete, with a reachy crux on a strange highstep to a horizontal crack after the 2nd-to-last bolt providing the crux. 

  This climb is shaded, even in summer evenings.
content.protection: 6 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with lowering biners. (The guidebook says 5 bolts but there are 6.)
content.location: Primal Scream is just right of the nice-looking crack Crisis in Utopia.  The start as the same as for Overkill, but go left after the 2nd bolt.

content.description: A slightly overhung green lichen covered arete. Harder than it looks and very full of lichen.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor
content.location: Just left of Just Say No to Jugs

content.description: The crux is off the deck on thin crimps up an overhang to some nice rounded pockets on a vertical face/arete section to a sweet exit. If you step over left at the bottom (crux), the route probably goes at 5.10b.
content.protection: 4 bolts and 2 fixed slings to a 2 bolt chained anchor.
content.location: This is the first bolted line to the right of Overlard.

content.description: This is a very enjoyable warm up on the North Side. It starts up a ramp with a hand crack in a left facing dihedral that gets wider as you go and then turns into a finger crack that exits out a steep overhang with excellent foot placements and secure jamming.
content.protection: 1-#2 Camalot, 1-#3 Camalot, 1-#5 Camalot, and 1-yellow Alien bring you to a nice 2 bolt anchor. The anchors will get chains on them soon.
content.location: This is the first obvious crack system to the left of C.O-R.F.S. Females

content.description: Start on the lefthand side of the slab, crank out over the roof which is the crux, then continue up the left arete/face to a shared exit and anchors with Overlard.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2 bolt chained anchor.
content.location: This is the 2nd bolted route you come to if coming from the south side. It is the left side of the obvious block roof.

content.description: Just around the corner from a greenish/licheny face is a slightly overhung route with huge holds. Begins from a large ledge.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor

content.description: Cruise up the right side of the obvious slab to a high spacey first clip off of a secure undercling, then pull the roof on large pockets and trend left to surmount the exit moves. The crux is pulling the roof without using the crack to the right, and staying on the face. It shases its last bolt, and anchors with Overloord. A fun and lively warm up. It gets morning shade and afternoon sun.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a two bolt chained anchor.
content.location: 1st route to the right of Overloord.

content.description:
Scramble up some choss, then a steep face route with a crux moving past the 2nd bolt as you make moves off of a blocky tower and into the shallow dihedral above.  Step right and climb the fun pocketed face. 

  This climb is shaded until late evening.
content.protection: 6 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.

content.description: Clip the first two bolts of Putterman Gully Jump, then head up and leftwards.
content.protection: 5 bolts (First two bolts are shared w/ Biomechanoid), 2-bolt anchor with lowering biners
content.location: Start as for Putterman Gully Jump

content.description: This climb is yet another nice moderate on the North Side that climbs a vertical finger crack that gets wider and exits left at the top. Harder than it looks.
content.protection: Stoppers, Aliens, and a #3 Camalot to a 2 bolt chained anchor that is shared with The Unknown 5.11d face sport route.
content.location: The obvious crack system to the right of Unknown, and also to the right of Huecos Rancheros.

content.description: An overhanging wall with monster pockets and some stellar climbing. The opening moves are a little tricky so don't blow the first clip as it is a horrible landing. Get the first bolt and let the fun pocket pumping begin, and then continue to the thin and tricky exit up onto a shelf. The crux is at the last bolt.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2 bolt chained anchor. Stick clip recommended.
content.location: 1st chalked up route to the left of Vasoconstrictor

content.description: Crank some entertaining moves past some large rounded jugs up a short overhanging wall. Harder than it looks, but its over quick. The crux is between bolts 2 and 4. Retro bolted by one of the FAs in 1998 because of many near grounders that occurred.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a two bolt chained anchor
content.location: This is the third bolted line to the right (west) of Overlard.

content.description: A steep face climb on (you guessed it) pockets.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor. [Anchor needs cleaning hardware.]
content.location: Just right of Chocolate Thunder.

content.description: A nice sequential black arete with a high first bolt and some balancy, sharp continuous moves. The crux is at the third bolt to easier climbing above.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2 bolt chained anchor.
content.location: This is the 11th bolted line from the left (east) end of The North Side. It is the first bolted line to the right of Vasoconstrictor, it starts on a large belay shelf.

content.description: A contrived boulder problem (don't touch the crack!) leads to easier and funner 5.10 face climbing.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor
content.location: Next route right of OFSCF.

content.description: This is an awesome finger crack up a left leaning open book that is very clean for the meat of the route. It starts via a fifth class scramble up to the crack proper. The bottom and top sections can be technically, a little cruxy. It remains fairly continuous at the grade, but the endurance crux is about 2/3rds of the way up. Can you say finger locks? This stellar route deserves to see a lot more traffic than it does. Go climb it!
content.protection: Medium stoppers, a double set of Aliens, and a few runners, get you to a two bolt chained anchor.
content.location: This is the obvious stunning finger crack in an open book directly to the left of Primal Scream.

content.description:
Another north side sport route. Gets very little traffic.  

  Vertical face with more pockets than it appears. Crux near 3rd bolt using a sequence of 2- and 1-finger pockets.  Slab finish.
content.protection: 5 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: 15 feet right of Hammertime.

content.description: Climb a dirty (not enough traffic) arete on small pockets.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Just right of Overlichen.

content.description: This often overlooked and unknown arete is perhaps the best route at Overlook, and it never sees traffic. Start on chossy slab to the first bolt of Lubeme then continue straight up the overhanging arete and crank like there is no tomorrow up some technical arete moves until you reach the anchors. This route has the feel of the aretes at Below The Old New Place, so it is a little out of character for the north side. Continuous at the grade.
content.protection:
7 bolts to an upgraded anchor [February 2020] with lowering hardware.

 Used to be a stupid 2 bolt anchor--bolts are three feet apart, on either side of the arete,--with no lowering hardware on them of any sort. Extend the draws on this and then retrieve draws from the top.
content.location: 1st bolted line to the left of Putterman Gully Jump.

content.description:
The often shady and cooler area at The Overlook.  One can escape the summer's heat and enjoy numerous bolted sport routes.   

  This side of the Overlook isn't as popular as the east side because it's shorter and it can be difficult to reach the anchors from the top to set top ropes on some of the climbs.  The bolted routes are high quality, as is the crack climb Crisis in Utopia, so a visit to the North Side of the Overlook is definitely worthwhile, but the first time visitor to the Overlook should stay probably on the Main Wall.
